articles.title: Warning to drivers as kids return to school across Australia
articles.summary: The feature is currently unavailable, but we're working to restore it. It's a warning to drivers as kids return to school across Australia, so drivers should try again later.       in the feature is unavailable, it will be restored later.

articles.title: Water crisis and national unity
articles.author: Waqar Hassan
articles.summary: Pakistan is facing a severe water crisis due to climate change. The Indus River, reliant on glacial meltwater, faces water shortages due to shrinking glaciers. Modern irrigation techniques could conserve as much as 40% of agricultural water usage. Large and small dams can be built to store excess water during the monsoon season. Diamer-Bhasha and Mohmand Dam projects are moving in the right direction.

articles.title: Heatwave: sleeping on beaches and staying social
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: At least 420 people died as a result of the Black Friday bushfires which swept across southeastern Australia in January 1939. Most human deaths occurred during the preceding heatwave. In the first fortnight of 1939, Adelaide endured 13 days of temperatures exceeding 34°C. Noel Weller, who lived on a suburban block in Glandore with his wife and two children, kept a daily diary. Irene Ingram lived in the closely-packed row cottages of Adelaide's East End in the 1930s with her husband and son and they used to sleep outdoors to escape the heat.

articles.title: Napa Climate Action Committee hears urgent warning
articles.summary: Napa County Climate Action Committee is preparing a guide to reduce local greenhouse gas emissions. The committee is overseeing the creation of a county regional climate action and adaptation plan. Andrew Isaacs, a geochemistry expert at UC Berkeley, teaches the subject at the committee. He lives in rural Napa County and has a low-carbon ranch producing wine.

articles.title: From snow to sun: Could climate change be causing extreme weather shifts?
articles.author: Nate Mauldin
articles.summary: There was a once-in-a-decade snowstorm in the Cape Fear last week and temperatures reaching 70 later this week. Dr. Yalei You teaches in the Department of Earth and Ocean Sciences at UNCW. His research involves analyzing satellite data to investigate whether climate change might be driving severe weather patterns.

articles.title: Record January heat of almost 27°C bakes Spain's Valencia
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Valencia registered its hottest January temperature of 26.9°C in records going back more than 150 years. West wind stoked exceptionally hot temperatures on the coast with some areas experiencing their warmest night on record from Sunday to Monday. Spain is on the front line of the climate crisis as longer, harsher and more frequent heatwaves bake the European country.

articles.title: Preliminary report suggests bird strikes caused recent Jeju Air crash in South Korea
articles.author: Chris Benson
articles.summary: Migratory bird strikes were the cause of last month's deadly plane crash in South Korea, according to multiple reports. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.   .  Â      in the current state of investigation.

articles.title: Just Stop Oil disrupts West End play The Tempest while Sigourney Weaver performs
articles.author: Hannah Roberts
articles.summary: Two Just Stop Oil supporters disrupted a West End performance of The Tempest starring Sigourney Weaver. They carried a sign that read '1.5 degrees is a global shipwreck' and launched a confetti cannon. Weaver was escorted off stage at the Theatre Royal in Drury Lane.

articles.title: Marine heatwave likely cause of mass fish deaths on WA's Pilbara coast, authorities say
articles.author: Alistair Bates
articles.summary: There was a mass fish kill off Western Australia's Pilbara coast earlier this month. More than 30,000 fish washed up dead at Gnoorea Beach, about 1,500 kilometres north of Perth. The phenomenon was detected in September last year and declared a moderate heatwave, but conditions have warmed since then. Sea surface temperatures are about 4 to 5 degrees Celsius above the long-term average in the north coast bioregion and 2 to 3 degrees more in the Gascoyne bioregsion. The Bureau of Meteorology expects marine heatwave conditions to continue throughout January and February.

articles.title: Rhode-Island Sized Iceberg Headed Toward Island Full Of Penguins And Seals
articles.author: Jan Wesner Childs
articles.summary: The largest iceberg in the world is headed toward South Georgia Island. South Georgia is home to a huge population of penguins and seals. The iceberg broke off from the Filchner Ice Shelf in 1986 and was at sea for decades, but it was confirmed to be moving again more than a year ago.

articles.title: When a Forecast Flops: Post-Hoc Rationalization in Climate Science
articles.author: Charles Rotter
articles.summary: Michael E. Mann's post-mortem analysis on the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season provides a fascinating case study in how climate forecasts go astray. Mann and his team predicted an 'extremely active' hurricane season, with a most likely estimate of 33 named storms, but the season produced just 18 or 19. This falls well below Mann's projected range of 27–39 storms.

articles.title: How the weather has challenged producers at opposite ends of state
articles.author: Judith Maizey
articles.summary: Far north Queensland producer says the weather over the past 12 months has been the most challenging he's ever experienced as a farmer and it's been especially difficult for farmers in the far north Queensland.    in the last 12 months. in the past year.

articles.title: UN Appeals for $910 Mln to Address Humanitarian Crisis in Nigeria
articles.author: Israa Farhan
articles.summary: The United Nations has launched a humanitarian appeal worth $910 million to address the urgent needs of 3.6 million people in Nigeria's northeastern states of Borno, Adamawa, and Yobe. The humanitarian crisis is exacerbated by ongoing conflict, climate shocks, and economic instability. In 2025, 33 million people will face severe food insecurity during the dry season.

articles.title: Pole Shifts and Climate Change
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: The Laschamps Excursion caused a temporary collapse of Earth's magnetic field 42,000 years ago. It was a geomagnetic event where the planet's magnetic poles weakened to less than 6% of their current strength and temporarily reversed. This period coincides with the extinction of many megafaunal species and significant disruptions to human populations. Evidence suggests that humans sought refuge in caves.

articles.title: Extreme weather raises hunger risk in Latin America, UN says
articles.author: Juana Casas
articles.summary: Climate variability and extreme weather events are increasing the risk of hunger and malnutrition in Latin America and the Caribbean. The economies of the region are heavily dependent on farming, ranching, forestry and fishing. Half of the countries analyzed considered likeable to face increased malnourishment.

articles.title: Climate Chaos: The Rising Hunger Threat in Latin America
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: At least 20 Latin American countries are at risk from climate change-induced droughts, floods, and storms. Half of these countries could see increased malnourishment due to extreme weather events. The region is the world's second most exposed area after Asia and is heavily dependent on agriculture.

articles.title: Lifelines for small island states
articles.author: Maya Delaney
articles.summary: Small island developing states (Sids) are on the front lines of climate change. Sids are home to 40% of the world's coral reefs, which shelter one-quarter of all marine life and directly support the livelihoods of 500 million people. In the Maldives, fishing and tourism account for up to 36% of GDP, while 98% of exports are derived from the ocean. The economy depends on healthy coral reefs and marine life, so Sids face negative feedback loops from interconnected economic and environmental challenges. The key to breaking these feedback loops is more financing.

articles.title: Australia news live: heatwave to hit Sydney as Victoria fights bushfires; Albanese to spruik childcare savings
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Families in south-eastern states have saved an average of $2,768 on average. Albanese government will help families in that state to get out of debt in Albanian government's aid package. The hot weather will continue in NSW, but cool change has already kicked in for south-east states.

articles.title: Island activists put a new spin on Groundhog Day and climate action
articles.author: Evan Lindsay
articles.summary: Groundhog's Guide to Suing Big Oil is a free public event being held on Groundhog Day (Feb. 2) at Broadview United Church, 3703 St. Aidans St. in Victoria. The event will feature video clips and presentations from speakers who will lead discussions on local climate action. The goal is to encourage local governments to join a class-action lawsuit against big oil companies.

articles.title: European cities face millions more deaths from extreme temperatures
articles.author: Michael Le Page
articles.summary: There will be an extra 2.3 million temperature-related deaths in Europe's main cities by 2099 without more action to limit warming and adapt to it. In cities in colder northern countries such as the UK, there will be fewer deaths due to cold because the decline in cold deaths will be greater than the increase in heat.

articles.title: We once sweated through heatwaves. Then air con transformed Australia
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australian's love of'manufactured air' also comes at a cost. Technology has shaped where and how Australians live for the past 30 years, but it's also quietly shaped their lives as well. It's a technology we barely notice but it has had a positive impact.

articles.title: Air conditioning quietly changed Australian life in just a few decades
articles.author: technology reporter
articles.summary: In 2000, about 35 per cent of Australian homes had air con, by 2010 it was 70 per cent, and in 2022 it will be 1.5 per cent. The number of air con units installed each year has risen from 330,000 in 2000 to 1 million in 2022.

articles.title: Lamont announces plan to tackle extreme weather and climate change
articles.author: Claudia S. Hilario
articles.summary: Governor Ned Lamont announced a detailed legislative plan to address Connecticut's growing vulnerability to extreme weather and climate change. 'Each year is bringing an increased number of extreme weather events and abnormal climate patterns that are direct threats to our homes and our lives,' Lamont said.

articles.title: New study predicts exactly how many people will die by 2099 all due to one thing
articles.author: Dan Grennan
articles.summary: Almost 6 million people are predicted to die by 2099. Barcelona is expected to be the city with the most heat-related deaths followed by Rome, Naples and Madrid. The most vulnerable areas to the sky-rocketing temperatures will be southern European nations such as the Mediterranean region and the Balkans.

articles.title: Rising Heat Waves: Europe's Looming Crisis by Century's End
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: By the end of this century, up to 2.3 million Europeans could die due to rising temperatures. The Mediterranean region faces a dramatic increase in temperature-induced mortality. Without drastic action, cities like Barcelona and Rome could witness staggering levels of heat-related fatalities.

articles.title: County working to identify damage to streams and waterways
articles.author: nick.fogleman
articles.summary: After Hurricane Helene, Watauga County is conducting a comprehensive stream assessment to identify and address issues impacting waterways. The county has released a self-reporting form for citizens to report the location of damage to waterways, including debris, erosion, landslides, and rerouted streams.

articles.title: Trump voters are not the obstacle to climate action many think they are
articles.author: Karl Dudman
articles.summary: Donald Trump has withdrawn the US from the Paris agreement on climate change. Karl Dudman spent a year in coastal North Carolina talking to people about the climate change and their attitude to it. He found that people there were sceptical about the science of climate change, but also interested in the social and political implications of it.

articles.title: Burbank Library Hosts Climate Conversation With Renowned Paleontologist And JPL Scientist
articles.author: Lisa Paredes
articles.summary: The Burbank Public Library hosts a climate conversation featuring paleontologist Neil Shubin and JPL glaciology expert Alex Gardner on Wednesday, February 5th at 7:30 p.m. at the Buena Vista Branch of the library. The event is free and open to the public and will discuss the history of the Earth's polar regions and their future.

articles.title: Mar-A-Lago under the parts of us predicted that they are under water at 2100 … Use our card to see if your house is at risk
articles.author: Jack
articles.summary: Global sea level could rise by 6.2 feet a year 2100 if the emission of carbon dioxide (CO2) continues to increase. New York, Boston, Atlantic City, Miami, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Charleston, North Carolina, Savannah, Georgia and Miami, Florida would be under water. The west coast would see fewer floods.

articles.title: Climate study warns of 2.3m more temperature-related deaths in Europe by 2099
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: Rising deaths from extreme heat will 'far exceed' reductions in numbers dying from cold temperatures in Europe with climate change, according to a study by the University of Cambridge.    "implausibly strong levels of adaptation" are needed to adapt to climate change.

articles.title: Climate study warns of 2.3m more temperature-related deaths in Europe by 2099
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: According to him, climate change can be greatly reduced if people's resilience to extreme weather is increased and if the move away from fossil fuels is sped up. He also points out that it will be more successful if we limit the amount of climate change that we are faced with by accelerating the move towards alternatives to fossil fuels.

articles.title: Canada Geese Cozy Up To Keep Warm As Colorado Temperatures Drop
articles.author: Nicole Bonaccorso
articles.summary: The geese were swimming in the water in Littleton, Colorado, on Saturday despite the freezing temperatures. It's typical for geese to huddle together in cold weather to share and conserve body heat. A single goose has about 20,000 to 25,000 feathers.

articles.title: Climate change threatens agricultural productivity in central Europe
articles.author: Madhyamam
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are reshaping Central Europe's agricultural landscape, reducing the productivity of once-fertile farmland. Changing climate patterns are pushing fertile zones northward and westward, according to a new study.     .

articles.title: Global warming to prevent 3.4 million deaths from cold ... but at a deadly cost
articles.author: Sarah Knapton
articles.summary: Global warming will prevent 3.4 million deaths from the cold in Europe by the end of the century, but excess heat will claim millions of lives on the Continent. Northerly European countries, including Britain, would see an overall mortality benefit from rising temperatures, while central and southern areas will face devastating consequences.

articles.title: Trump's climate orders and Maryland's budget crisis demand bold action now
articles.summary: Maryland is vulnerable to climate change impacts like rising seas, flooding and extreme heat. Extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and severe, threatening lives, livelihoods, and infrastructure. The state is facing a budget crisis. The RENEW Act, HB340 and the coal fee legislation would make polluters pay for the damage they've caused.

articles.title: Climate Change Fuels Forced Migrations, Deepening Africa's Challenges
articles.author: Ecofin Agency
articles.summary: Extreme weather events have been highlighted as one of the leading global risks in the WEF's Global Risks Perception Survey (GRPS) 2025. The effects of climate change are deeply intertwined with many other global risks, including the mass migration of people. Sub-Saharan Africa alone faces an estimated cost of $30 to $50 billion annually over the next decade due to climate change.

articles.title: CLIMATE ANXIETY: A manufactured crisis fueled by fear and propaganda
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: A study published in The Lancet Planetary Health claims that climate change is causing widespread anxiety among young Americans. Critics argue that the study is more about advancing a political agenda than presenting scientific facts. The study's methodology has drawn sharp criticism for its reliance on self-reported data and a non-representative sample.

articles.title: Mar-a-Lago among swathes of US predicted to be underwater by 2100... use our map to see if YOUR home's at risk
articles.author: ELLYN LAPOINTE
articles.summary: Global sea levels could rise by 6.2 feet by the year 2100 if carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions continue to increase. People living on the East Coast would be hit the hardest with large portions of New York City, Boston, Atlantic City and Miami submerged. President Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida will also be underwater in 75 years. The West Coast was predicted to see less flooding even though scientists have long said that the entire state of California would be underwater.

articles.title: Russia Sees Rapid 3 C Winter Temperature Increase Over Past 50 Years
articles.author: The Moscow Times
articles.summary: Winter temperatures in Russia have risen by an average of 3 degrees Celsius over the past half-century, according to Alexei Kokorin, a climate expert at the Nature and People Foundation. 2024 saw the warmest temperatures recorded in 170 years along Lake Baikal. Russia has been warming at more than twice the global average since 1976.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.title: Grab some binoculars and start counting: NH Audubon annual bird survey taking place Feb. 8-9.
articles.summary: The Backyard Winter Bird Survey is taking place on Feb. 8 and 9 in New Hampshire. It's the 38th year of the survey. Last year there were over 1,500 participants. Dr. Pamela Hunt predicts high counts of Red-breasted Nuthatches and Red-bellied Woodpeckers this year.

articles.title: Study projects millions of European heat deaths as world warms
articles.author: Seth Borenstein
articles.summary: Extreme temperatures are projected to kill as many as 2.3 million people in Europe by the end of the century unless countries get better at reducing carbon pollution and adapting to hotter conditions. Cold temperatures kill more people than heat by large margins. London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine used climate simulations of different scenarios and looked at death rates in 854 cities.

articles.title: How did Houston freeze last week? It had a McFarland Signature, named for a Texas scientist
articles.author: Mary Wasson
articles.summary: Last week's winter freeze followed a weather pattern that weather scientists call a 'McFarland Signature'. This refers to an air flow in the upper levels of the atmosphere that dislodges large areas of arctic air in Canada and sends it southward through the Great Plains and into Texas. The weather service has archived some of Marshall J. McFarland's research online.

articles.title: Climate change could cause millions more temperature-related deaths in Europe by 2099, study says
articles.author: Rosie Frost
articles.summary: Barcelona is projected to see the highest temperature-related death toll by the end of the century at 246,082. It is followed by two Italian cities: Rome with 147,738 deaths and Naples with 146,248. Madrid, Athens, Valencia, Marseille, Bucharest and Genoa round out the 10 worst-affected cities. Europe is warming faster than any other continent on Earth.

articles.title: Wall St falls as DeepSeek competition pulls down Nasdaq
articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.title: A climate change denier? Who, me?
articles.summary: Donald Trump is a climate change denier. Harold A. Black is not in the camp that believes that climate change constitutes an existential threat. He has constructed econometric models his entire professional life. He questions the reliability of climate change models and their predictive power.

articles.title: Study projects millions of European heat deaths as world warms
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Extreme temperatures are projected to kill as many as 2.3 million people in Europe by the end of the century unless countries get better at reducing carbon pollution and adapting to hotter conditions. Cold deaths lessen slowly as the climate warms, but heat deaths soar rapidly as it warms.

articles.title: Study projects millions of European heat deaths as world warms
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Extreme temperatures are projected to kill as many as 2.3 million people in Europe by the end of the century unless countries get better at reducing carbon emissions. The study was published in the journal "Environmental Research Letters".  .    "The World Energy Report" is available here.

articles.title: Study projects millions of European heat deaths as world warms
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: Extreme temperatures are projected to kill as many as 2.3 million people in Europe by the end of the century unless countries get better at reducing carbon pollution and adapting to hotter conditions. Italy, southern Spain and Greece should see massive increases in the rate of heat deaths due to climate change. Scandinavia and the United Kingdom will see fewer temperature-related deaths.

articles.title: Dangerous temperatures could kill 50% more Europeans by 2100, study finds
articles.author: Ajit Niranjan
articles.summary: By the end of the century, there will be 50% more temperature-related deaths in Europe than there are currently. The death toll is set to rise the most in hot southern Europe, particularly around the Mediterranean and central Europe. Cool northern Europe is expected to see a small decrease.

articles.title: Terrifying study predicts exactly how many people will DIE from climate change by 2099
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: Barcelona will see the highest temperature-related death toll by the end of the century, followed by Rome, Napes and Madrid. The most vulnerable areas of Europe to heat deaths will be further south, in the Mediterranean region and the Balkans. The study focuses on daily mean temperature and does not account for specific weather events.

articles.title: Florida Experienced Cold Weather in January. What to Expect in February?
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: January has been very cold in Florida. Temperatures are starting to return to normal for the last week of the month. February will be warmer than normal for most of the south and east United States. The atmosphere needs a second to recharge after last week's historic snowfall.

articles.title: January was frigid in Florida. What's the forecast for February?
articles.author: David Nazario
articles.summary: Temperatures in Florida are starting to return to normalcy for many of us. Climate Prediction Center is anticipating a massive flip in overall temperatures across Florida and the rest of the south and east United States. After such a historic event last week, the atmosphere needs a second to recharge.

articles.title: Digital Diplomacy: How Sinking Nations Are Advocating For Survival Online
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Small island nations are on the frontlines of the climate crisis. Rising sea levels threaten their physical territories and their cultural identity and global representation. They are increasingly leveraging digital tools and platforms to advocate for their survival and safeguard their sovereignty. Digital diplomacy has emerged in this context.

articles.title: What to know about Trump's first executive actions on climate and environment
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: President Trump's first week in office included a flurry of executive orders with implications for Earth's climate and environment. Trump's moves to step away from global climate action, ramp up domestic oil and gas production and remove incentives for electric vehicles are worrisome as the planet continues to heat up.

articles.title: Thousands of cranes overwinter in central Nebraska: 'Past few years have been kind of crazy'
articles.author: Marjie Ducey
articles.summary: About 10,000 to 15,000 sandhill cranes have overwintered on a stretch of the Platte River from Wood River to Grand Island in central Nebraska for the second straight year. The temperature this season has been 39 degrees, compared with previous season averages of 37.4 degrees. The area has received a half-inch of snow this season, compared to normal totals of 9.6 inches. There is no snow in the Kearney area. The birds have been able to continue to feed in cornfields on existing waste grain.

articles.title: 40% Reduction in rainfall slashes crop yields in Punjab, Pakistan, threatening agriculture
articles.summary: In Punjab, Pakistan, a severe winter drought has led to a 40% reduction in rainfall from September to mid-January, affecting agriculture. Agriculture contributes nearly a quarter of Pakistan's GDP and employs 37% of the workforce. Pakistan's reliance on the Indus River, rapid population growth and inadequate water management pose a significant challenge for agriculture.

articles.title: Global GDP Faces 50% Loss Without Climate Change Action, Study Finds
articles.author: Jamie Hailstone
articles.summary: The global economy could contract by 50% between 2070 and 2090 without urgent action on climate change and nature loss. Global populations are already impacted by food system shocks, water insecurity, heat stress and infectious diseases. If the situation remains unchecked, mass mortality, mass displacement, severe economic contraction and conflict will become more likely.

articles.title: Global sea level may rise by up to 1.9m by 2100, exceeding earlier projections: NTU study
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: The UN climate science body projected that sea levels would rise up to 1m by 2100, according to the UN IPCC. The IPCC also projected that the temperature would rise by 1.5 degrees Celsius by the end of the century, if the climate change is not stopped.

articles.title: CNY travel rush: Chinese government estimates 9 billion trips across country over 40 days
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Record number of trips are expected between mid-January and February in China to mark Chinese New Year. This is a seven per cent increase from 2024, when the number reached 8.4 billion trips over the 40-day period. Tan Yew Guan reports from Shanghai.

articles.title: Ag Chat with Kristin Smith (1/27)
articles.summary: Ag Chat with Kristin Smith is at 6 am (1/27). First Alert Weather is a late month thaw as temperatures moderate this week. Garage Sustains Heavy Damage After House Fire and a pair of pants for Tomah Fire Department is needed. Highground Host Bowling Fundraiser.

articles.title: Trump's climate orders and Maryland's budget crisis demand bold action now
articles.author: Jennifer Laszlo Mizrahi
articles.summary: Maryland is vulnerable to climate change impacts. The state is facing a budget crisis. The RENEW Act establishes a fund for climate resilience projects funded by fossil fuel companies. The Climate Lawsuit Authority enables Maryland to hold Fossil Fuel Companies accountable in court for their role in causing climate damage. Speaker Pro Tem Dana Stein's upcoming bill will place a fee on coal transportation in Maryland, directing approximately $300 million a year toward renewable energy projects and public health programs.

articles.title: 2025 declared as international year of glaciers
articles.author: Manila Standard
articles.summary: The UN General Assembly declared 2025 the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation (IYGP). Melting ice and glaciers threaten long-term water security for many millions of people. This international year must be a wake-up call to the world, according to UNEOS.

articles.title: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for Kirkland Lake area
articles.author: Northern News staff
articles.summary: Environment Canada has issued a winter weather travel advisory for the Kirkland Lake area. It is cold and snowy in the area, but not as bad as it was in Sudbury and near it. It's snowing near Sudbury, but it's not snowing where it was before.

articles.title: School closings, delays in Western North Carolina, Monday, Jan. 27
articles.author: Todd Runkle
articles.summary: Some school systems in Western North Carolina are closed or operating on delays Monday, Jan. 27, due to winter weather impacts. Avery County Schools are on a three-hour delay, Madison County Schools: Three hours delay, Mitchell County Schools three-hours delay, Watauga County Schools closed and Yancey County Schools on three- hours delay.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.title: Sun sees powerful flare on January 27
articles.author: TASS
articles.summary: The level of impact of solar X-ray bursts on the Earth's ionosphere has increased since the flare. It's now at R1 (weak) level on a five-point scale topping out at R5 (extreme) or extreme.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.title: How the Mafia is weaponizing wildfires
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: There are more than 8,000 wildfires in Sicily in 2021. More than half of them are started intentionally. The Mafia is 'weaponizing' fire in the region for control and financial gain, according to UC Berkeley researcher Lauren Pearson. In 2023, half of Italy's nearly 3,700 fires occurred in Sicily, Puglia, Calabria and Campania.

articles.title: Lara Williams: Trump isn't the biggest threat facing Greenland
articles.author: Lara Williams
articles.summary: Greenland is one of the few places on Earth where climate change is considered an opportunity. Warming temperatures and receding glaciers make precious minerals easier to access, extend the growing season on the south of the island and bring new species of fish to the self-ruling territory's waters. The island's mineral wealth and strategic location are why President Donald Trump wants to buy the territory.

articles.title: The first temperature records of 2025 were recorded in Kyiv: the indicators exceeded the norm by almost 10 degrees
articles.author: Iryna Perepechko
articles.summary: Kyiv recorded its first temperature records of the year on Sunday, January 26. The maximum air temperature reached 7.4 °C, which is 0.5 °C higher than the highest readings for this day, which were set in 2021. Kyiv has not had a climatic winter for three years in a row. In Kyiv, 2024 was the warmest year on record.

articles.title: The cities that will be 'submerged by global warming'
articles.author: Shivali Best
articles.summary: Scientists from Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore, have predicted that global sea levels could rise by 6.2 feet (1.9 metres) by 2100 if CO2 emissions continue to increase. If sea levels rise by that amount, coastal towns and cities around the world could be plunged underwater. People living on the east coast of England would be worst hit.

articles.title: A young local power couple have taken up key roles at Imperials Football Club, aiming for greater inclusivity
articles.summary: The rise of neo-nazis in Australia's backyard is a problem for Australia Premium.   .      in Australia Premium's opinion article.  "The Rise of Neo-Nazis" is published by Australia Premium, a premium service.

articles.title: Virginia legislation attempts to combat growing impacts of climate crisis
articles.author: Jim Morrison
articles.summary: There are a record number of climate change-related bills in the Virginia General Assembly this year. Legislation introduced this session calls for creating a task force to develop a statewide wetlands strategy to restore, create, and plan for their migration as sea level rises. The Coastal Resilience Master Plan estimates up to 89% of Virginia's tidal wetlands could be lost by 2080.

articles.title: Climate Change: A Growing Threat to Pakistan's Agriculture
articles.author: Muhammad Abdullah Qaisar
articles.summary: Rising temperatures, shifting rainfall patterns, and more frequent extreme weather events are threatening Pakistan's agriculture sector. The most immediate impact of climate change on agriculture is the decline in crop yields and quality. Climate change threatens the food security of millions of Pakistanis, especially those living in rural areas. Pakistan needs to implement adaptation and mitigation strategies, promote sustainable agricultural practices, and seek international cooperation to deal with climate change.

articles.title: Letter: Act boldly on climate change, enact visitor fee
articles.summary: The governor's Climate Advisory Team recommended a resilience fund to deal with climate change. It's not fair to ask residents to pay more in taxes, especially when the gap is over $500 million a year. A visitor fee has been proposed for many years, which would raise the funding we need.

articles.title: How ocean temps are driving LA firestorms
articles.summary: In recent decades, the climate has gotten hotter, drier and more variable due to more intense rains and droughts in California. The most recent urban firestorm that has raged across Los Angeles for over a week will likely become the most expensive natural disaster in U.S. history. Arctic Ocean is warming three times faster than the rest of the world due to a phenomenon known as 'Arctic amplification' and vanishing sea ice. The Heritage Foundation's Project 2025 agenda calls for NOAA to be 'broken up and downsized' so it stops contributing to 'the climate change alarm industry'.

articles.title: Resilience is not just about infrastructure' Sherry Rehman
articles.summary: Senator Sherry Rahman is the Chairperson of the Senate Standing Committee on Environmental Change. She stressed the need for Adaptive Social Protection (ASP) to support vulnerable communities in Pakistan. Senator Rehman highlighted the importance of social protection programs like the Benazir Income Support Program (BISP), which provided assistance to 2.5 million families during the 2022 floods.

articles.title: Judge dismisses Annapolis, Anne Arundel's claims for climate change damages
articles.author: Racquel Bazos
articles.summary: Anne Arundel Circuit Court Judge Steven Platt dismissed the suits against energy industry giants in their pursuit of damages from the effects of climate change. Plaintiffs argued the energy companies deceived the public about the effect of fossil fuels on the environment and were in part responsible for the damage incurred by climate catastrophes, such as flooding and sea level rise.

articles.title: Chris Dollar: Frigid temperatures threaten game fish such as speckled seatrout  OUTDOORS COMMENTARY

articles.author: Dispatch Argus
articles.summary: An iceberg known as A23a is visible as it heads toward South Georgia Island on Jan. 15 off the coast of Antarctica, heading toward the South Georgia Sea.      .   "A23a" is a large iceberg.

articles.title: ‘Worldwide epidemic': Expert warns against the use of lithium-ion batteries due to fire risk
articles.summary: Lithium-ion batteries are causing more than 10,000 fires per year in Australia. Steve Goreham, Executive Director of the Climate Science Coalition of America, warns against the government's investment in lithium batteries.      .   i

articles.title: Warning to homeowners with a chimney over when to stop using it
articles.author: Sally McLean
articles.summary: The RSPB has issued a warning to homeowners with chimneys to prevent birds nesting in their chimneys. The most common bird to build nests in chimneys is a Jackdaw. The chimney should be swept regularly and a cowl fitted to the chimney pot to prevent access.

articles.title: Schooling of 33 million Bangladeshi kids hit by climate crises in 2024
articles.author: Climate
articles.summary: Severe weather events disrupted education for children around the world, including 33 million children in Bangladesh in 2024. At least 247 million students in 77 countries had their schooling disrupted by heat waves, tropical storms, floods and droughts. South Asia was the most affected region.

articles.title: Extreme fire danger grips Australia's southeast amid heatwave
articles.author: Mehr News Agency
articles.summary: Temperatures could reach 41 degrees Celsius (105.8 degrees Fahrenheit) in Melbourne on Monday. The fire danger is at extreme in five Victorian regions. New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory are under heatwave alerts. The weather forecaster predicts the heatwave will intensify on Tuesday.

articles.title: UN urges global action to preserve glaciers amid rapid melting
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The world's glaciers cover 700,000 square kilometers and store 70% of the world's freshwater. They are melting away at an increasing pace due to man-made climate change. The agencies launched the International Year of Glaciers' Preservation in Geneva. The launch came after President Trump announced he would withdraw from the Paris Agreement.

articles.title: A trip to see family leads to life-changing decision for Catherene Robinson
articles.summary: The Phillipino woman moved to Australia six years ago and she loves it more and more now that she's had six years to learn about the country. She had a few culture shocks when she first moved there, but now she's more comfortable with it than before.

articles.author: The Epoch Times

articles.author: Faridah Abdulkadiri

The soaring temperatures revived memories of the devastating 2019-2020 'Black Summer' fires, which destroyed an area equivalent to Turkey, claimed 33 lives and killed billions of animals.

articles.author: TOI Science Desk
articles.summary: The magnetic North Pole was discovered 400 km from Canada in 1831 and has since drifted towards Russia. The movement of the pole is recorded with the help of the World Magnetic Model, compiled every five years. It is important for navigation systems and to understand Earth's magnetic field.

articles.title: Opinion: Wildfires are a window into the future we don't want to conside
articles.summary: Jonathan P. Baird lives in Wilmot, California. He is concerned about the L.A. wildfire and the climate change denialism. Fossil fuel companies knew about climate change as far back as the 1970s, but they hired a small army of public relations experts to sow doubt about it.

articles.title: Hunger: Delayed summer rains in much of Southern Africa to compound region's misery
articles.author: Ed Stoddard
articles.summary: Last year's El Niño devastated the grain-growing areas of southern Africa. The rains this summer have been late and the long-range forecasts are clouded by uncertainty, raising the spectre of more crop failures. An estimated 30 million people in the region are already experiencing critical food shortages.

articles.author: Crystal-Rose Jones
articles.summary: The world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa, was lit up with the Aussie flag for the second time this month on Jan. 25. articles.title: FAO, Canada, Jamaica launch gender-responsive, climate-smart agriculture project
articles.summary: The Gender-responsive Climate-smart Agriculture and Food Systems in the Caribbean (GCAF) project was launched last Thursday at the S Hotel in St Andrew. The project focuses on empowering youth, women, and producer organisations by addressing gender constraints and introducing climate-smart technologies and practices to improve livelihoods and food security in the region. It will be implemented in partnership with the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Mining in Jamaica.

articles.title: Food security and climate resilience: an essential link for the future
articles.summary: Latin America and the Caribbean is at a critical juncture in its fight against hunger and malnutrition. Meeting of Agriculture Ministers of CELAC 2025 will be held in Comayagua, Honduras in early February.

articles.summary: Storm Eowyn is the latest in a long line of climate catastrophes that are growing more frequent and intense. The most vulnerable in society will be the most affected by the storm. The first step is to build one community food hub for every 500 households and provide free meals to everyone.

articles.title: Giant iceberg is on a collision course with island home to seals and penguins
articles.summary: The world's biggest iceberg, A23a, is on a collision course with South Georgia. The iceberg broke away from the Antarctic ice sheet in 1986, but it was stuck on the ground for 34 years. Scientists think climate change is leading to a growing number of icebergs.

articles.summary: Flash floods have become a significant and increasingly frequent natural disaster in Namibia due to climate change and urbanisation. To safeguard lives, the government is taking steps to prevent future flash floods in the country. Oluibukun Gbenga Ajayi is one of them.

articles.title: ‘Sustainable architectural designs will mitigate climate crisis'
articles.author: Victor Gbonegun
articles.summary: The building and construction sector is the largest emitter of greenhouse gases, accounting for 37 per cent of global emissions. The recent devastating floods in various parts of Nigeria highlighted infrastructure vulnerabilities. There are calls for innovative architectural solutions such as flood-resilient building designs that can withstand nature's wrath.

articles.title: ‘Mind-blowing' cuts in greenhouse gases needed for Ireland to meet climate pledges, scientist warns
articles.author: Caroline O'Doherty
articles.summary: Professor Kevin Anderson says Ireland needs to cut CO2 emissions by 30% annually to be in line with the global goal of keeping temperature rise from exceeding 1.5C. Prof Anderson is an expert in energy and climate change at the universities of Manchester, Bergen and Uppsala. His warning comes before a High Court hearing tomorrow in which environmental and human rights campaigners accuse the State of failing to meet its climate-action commitments.

articles.title: Residents in Victoria and South Australia on alert for 'uncontrollable' bushfires amid heatwave warnings
articles.author: Rachael Ward
articles.summary: Temperatures are set to soar into the 40s across most of Australia. Extreme fire danger is forecast for western and central Victoria and much of eastern South Australia. A total fire ban is in place for the Wimmera, Mallee, southwest, central, central and north-central regions of Victoria and eastern parts of South Australia, including metropolitan Adelaide, Murraylands and Lower Eyre Peninsula. Southern Tasmania is also under a fire ban due to hot, dry windy conditions.

articles.title: Threat of 'uncontrollable' bushfires

A total fire ban is in place for the Wimmera, Mallee, southwest, central, central and north central regions of Victoria, as well as eastern parts of South Australia including metropolitan Adelaide, Murraylands and Lower Eyre Peninsula. Southern Tasmania is also under a fire ban. Heatwave warnings are current for South Australia, Queensland, NSW, ACT and Western Australia.

articles.title: Tell the truth
articles.author: Gwynne Dyer
articles.summary: The world's average temperature did exceed 1.5°C over the pre-industrial level in 2024, but this does not mean the long-term goal is shot, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. Scientists and politicians have been telling us for 10 years that we must never exceed that 'aspirational' +1.5 °C target or very bad things will follow.

articles.title: From melting glaciers to flood management
articles.author: Abdul Ghani Soomro
articles.summary: Pakistan's hydrological system is under pressure due to climate change, unsustainable practices, and rapid population growth. Glaciers in the northern mountains of Pakistan are melting at an unprecedented rate. The glaciers of the Karakoram, Hindu Kush, and Himalayan ranges are the primary water source for the Indus River. Pakistan's burgeoning population is projected to reach over 300 million by 2050. Agriculture consumes over 90 per cent of the country's water resources. Floods and droughts present challenges for Pakistan's water security.

Pervis Marker has researched penguin ecology for the last 30 years and co-ordinates the volunteer group Friends of Burnie Penguins. Food supply for penguins had been steady along the North-West Coast, from Devonport to Stanley, which meant numbers were stable. There might be up to 400,000 breeding pairs of Tasmanian little penguins.

articles.title: Happy feet on the Coast: Prime time for penguin viewing this summer

articles.summary: Penguin colonies on the North-West Coast have not experienced population decline relative to the East Coast due to the region's cooler waters, according to a Burnie-based penguin researcher. The East Coast has experienced a population decline due to warmer waters.

articles.author: The Peninsula
articles.summary: Valencia registered its hottest January temperature of 26.9 degrees Celsius on Monday. The previous record was 26.6 degrees Celsius recorded on January 22, 2018 in a data set going back more than 150 years, according to the national weather agency. The measurement broke the previous record set in 1978.

The forest offers valuable insights about past climate change.      .   i

articles.title: Surviving drought
articles.author: Maria Hameed
articles.summary: There has been a significant drop in rainfall in Pakistan over the past four months. There have been erratic rainfall patterns in recent years, with the country lurching from monsoon deluges to drought-like conditions. This type of erratic weather is down to climate change and demands urgent and effective mitigation strategies.
